content: email ellen@knittipoliti com 3 making up step 1 start with the right side of the work facing and top loop strip at the top of the work step 2 fold the piece so that the cast-on and bound-off ends meet in the centre of the piece the wrong side of the work is now facing sew straight across the bottom using a backstitch seam step 3 with wrong side still facing bring the row edges of the top of the work together and sew straight across the top copyright © ellen kapusniak 2014 for pattern support email ellen@knittipoliti com 4 back stitch with work together and wrong sides facing outwards insert needle through both layers from from front to back and pull through start point make a small stitch inserting needle from back to front and pull through reinsert the needle at the start point from front to back and pull through continue making stitches in this way working into the start point of each stitch tip for success you can use any seaming method you prefer back stitch seams have been included in the instructions as they are simple to sew and give strength and structure to the pod which helps it to stand up crochet seams are also a sturdy choice for this design note for left-handed knitters the little loop strip will be on the other side of the work to that pictured but all making up will be the same finishing turn right side out fold the top loop strip in half and stitch in place at the top of the opening use a few stitches to sew the opening shut a little at the top and bottom of the pod if desired fold toggle loop in half and sew in place halfway down the pod at one side of the opening sew the toggle in place on the other side copyright © ellen kapusniak 2014 for pattern support email ellen@knittipoliti com 5 customisation ideas resizing to make larger or smaller pods cast on multiples of 4 sts plus enough extra to produce the top loop which will be bound off on the first row the toggle loop is the same size as the top loop so it could be worked first to test how many stitches will look good for the top loop using a different yarn weight any weight of yarn could be used just pick a needle size that will ensure that the gauge is not too loose the knitted piece needs a certain amount of stiffness particularly if making pods larger than the ones in the pattern note if modifying the pod pattern to a different stitch count or using a different weight of yarn and different needles all that is needed for the design to work is to make sure that the length of the knitted piece is twice its width measure the width when the length seems to be roughly at the halfway point this will give a more accurate
